members.name: Corine 2018 (Copernicus)
members.description: CLC2018 is one of the Corine Land Cover (CLC) datasets produced within the frame the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service referring to land cover / land use status of year 2018. CLC service has a long-time heritage (formerly known as "CORINE Land Cover Programme"), coordinated by the European Environment Agency (EEA). It provides consistent and thematically detailed information on land cover and land cover changes across Europe. CLC datasets are based on the classification of satellite images produced by the national teams of the participating countries - the EEA members and cooperating countries (EEA39).National CLC inventories are then further integrated into a seamless land cover map of Europe. The resulting European database relies on standard methodology and nomenclature with following base parameters: 44 classes in the hierarchical 3-level CLC nomenclature; minimum mapping unit (MMU) for status layers is 25 hectares; minimum width of linear elements is 100 metres. Change layers have higher resolution, i.e. minimum mapping unit (MMU) is 5 hectares for Land Cover Changes (LCC), and the minimum width of linear elements is 100 metres. The CLC service delivers important data sets supporting the implementation of key priority areas of the Environment Action Programmes of the European Union as e.g. protecting ecosystems, halting the loss of biological diversity, tracking the impacts of climate change, monitoring urban land take, assessing developments in agriculture or dealing with water resources directives. CLC belongs to the Pan-European component of the Copernicus Land Monitoring Service ( https://land.copernicus.eu/ ), part of the European Copernicus Programme coordinated by the European Environment Agency, providing environmental information from a combination of air- and space-based observation systems and in-situ monitoring. Additional information about CLC product description including mapping guides can be found at https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/clc2018technicalguidelines_final.pdf. CLC class descriptions can be found at https://land.copernicus.eu/user-corner/technical-library/corine-land-cover-nomenclature-guidelines/html/ .

members.name: Land use capacity
members.description:
Regional land use capacity maps produced by the regions Basilicata, Emilia-Romagna, Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Lazio, Lombardy, Piedmont, Sardinia, Tuscany and Veneto.​
Regions for which data is not present have not made the land use capacity map available or have not defined it.
In this layer, regional land use capacity maps have been standardized to obtain a single classification in the 8 classes defined below. ​
Land use capacity provides indications on soil potential to host and favor the growth of cultivated and wild plants. The estimation methodology provides classification on the basis of production potential and only considers permanent physical-chemical parameters of the soil, without taking into account economic-strategic considerations or characteristics or qualities that can be modified with specific interventions.

Soils are classified into:

  • Class I - Little or no restrictions on use. Wide range of crop choices and land uses.

  • Class II - Moderate limitations that partially reduce productivity or require some conservative practices.

  • Class III - Heavy limitations that reduce crop choices, productivity and/or require special conservation practices.

  • Class IV - Very evident limitations which restrict the choice of crops and require very careful management to contain the degradation.

  • Class V - Limitations that are difficult to eliminate and strongly restrict agricultural uses. Pasture and forest are possible uses together with naturalistic conservation.

  • Class VI - Severe limitations that make soils generally unsuitable for cultivation and limit their use to grazing, forestation, woodland or naturalistic and landscape conservation.

  • Class VII - Very severe limitations that make the soils unsuitable for production activities and that restrict their use to natural forest, naturalistic and landscape conservation.

  • Class VIII - Limitations that totally preclude the productive use of the land, restricting the uses to the recreational and touristic function, to the naturalistic conservation, to the water reserve and to the protection of the landscape.

The first four classes essentially indicate soils suitable for cultivation and other uses, class V indicates soils that can be used for agricultural purposes only under certain conditions, while the last classes indicate soils unsuitable for cultivation.
Based on regional decisions, high capacity soils can be considered as a territorial limitation to the exploitation and development of RES.​

members.name: Marine Cartography
members.description: This collection includes information on bathymetry and main territorial limits within marine areas.

members.name: Bathymetry (m)
members.description: Bathymetry reclassified from data from the European Marine Observation and Data Network (EMODnet) DTM for European sea regions (2018) https://www.emodnet-bathymetry.eu/metadata-data.
